SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say that I always get a little worried when I find that I agree with some of the comments made by the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), but I must say that I heartily endorse most of what he said in relation to the bill we are debating at the moment—the Evidence and Procedure (New Zealand) Bill 1993. This bill makes a lot of sense and it reflects the ever closer relations between those people living in Australia and those across the Tasman in New Zealand. The bill provides for cooperation between Australia and New Zealand in relation to the service and enforcement of subpoenas, the taking of evidence by video link or telephone and the taking of judicial notice of public and official acts and documents, including judicial notice of New Zealand laws.

PARA.TAB: The bill is designed to produce similar arrangements to that of the Trade Practices (Misuse of Trans-Tasman Market Power) Act 1990, which provided for the exercise of jurisdiction by the Federal Court of Australia in New Zealand in relation to certain antitrust matters and for the exercise in Australia of jurisdiction by the High Court of New Zealand in like antitrust matters. The bill amended the Trade Practices Act 1974 to allow for the implementation of Australia's obligations under the Australia-New Zealand closer economic relations trade agreement on the acceleration of free trade and goods. The act also provided for mutual assistance, including the taking of evidence in one country for use by the court of the other. There was also provision for the reciprocal enforcement of judgments given in antitrust matters. The Evidence and Procedure (New Zealand) Bill 1993 covers a broader scope and is not limited to financial matters.

The New Zealand parliament introduced complementary legislation in September last year. This bill is expected to result in a reduction in the cost of litigation before Australian courts involving New Zealand elements. Under current arrangements, unless a witness is prepared to attend voluntarily, evidence has to be obtained between the two countries by a letter of request to judicial authorities or arrangements have to be made for evidence to be taken on commission, as opposed to obtaining evidence from a witness directly during the course of a proceeding. These methods, as could be imagined, have proven to be cumbersome and certainly can be expensive.

This bill is not expected to make any impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue and, as indicated by my colleague the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), who is the shadow minister representing the shadow Attorney-General in this place, the coalition will not be opposing this bill.

There are seven main parts to this bill. Part 1 of the bill, which includes proposed sections 3 and 4, is non-controversial and defines the terms used throughout. Clause 3 covers the term `family proceeding', which includes proceedings relating to marriage or divorce, maintenance of a spouse or former spouse, property arising out of a marriage or out of a de facto relationship, protection of people from domestic violence, the status or property of a person who is not able to manage his or her own affairs, as well as child guardianship, custody, access, maintenance, paternity and adoption.

The clause also provides for the definition of `spouse' to include a de facto spouse. It could be argued both ways on that, but certainly the coalition is not opposing what the government is seeking to do at this time. Clause 4 provides a definition of `court' for the purpose of this bill and it states that a tribunal is a court if the regulations so provide.

Part 2 of the bill deals with Australian subpoenas. The proposed section 7 provides that this segment of the bill concerns subpoenas issued in proceedings in a federal court or a court of a state or territory specified in the regulations. This proposed section does not apply to subpoenas issued in criminal or family proceedings. I might add that these exclusions were in fact sought by the New Zealand authorities.

Proposed section 8 authorises subpoenas to be served in New Zealand and service to be subject to applicable rules of the court and to regulations and may require attendance by a named person at a place in Australia or New Zealand. When a subpoena is to be served in New Zealand, leave for service must be given by a superior court judge and the judge must take into account the significance of the evidence, the document or thing to be produced, and whether the evidence, document or thing could be obtained by other means without significantly greater expense and with less inconvenience to the person named. The judge must impose a date after which the subpoena cannot be served, and leave may not be granted where the person named is under 18 years of age.

The subpoena can be set aside in certain instances by application of the person on whom it is served and, if the subpoena requires a production of documents, it must permit compliance by producing the documents to a registrar of the High Court of New Zealand.

Part 3 of the bill deals with New Zealand subpoenas. This section provides that a New Zealand subpoena which is in appropriate form and correctly served must be complied with. That makes sense. Non-compliance with the subpoena constitutes contempt of the Federal Court of Australia. Part 3 also allows for the receipt of documents or things required by subpoena by a New Zealand court to be received by the registry of specified Australian courts, with the court notifying the New Zealand court by facsimile or electronic mail of the receipt of the document or thing in transmitting it to the New Zealand court.

Part 4 of the bill is concerned with the use of video links and telephones in Australian proceedings. It allows that Australian courts may direct that evidence be taken or submissions made by video link or telephone from New Zealand, provided facilities are available and it is convenient to do so. This applies to civil or criminal proceedings.

Yesterday, in the Main Committee, we debated the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs had some concerns in relation to video link evidence, because it was looking at taking evidence from countries in South-East Asia which may not have the technology or the ability to make proper use of video link evidence which would not only be at reasonable cost but also would preserve the interests of justice and fairness for the accused. However, I have no concerns with New Zealand, because I think New Zealand is similarly technologically advanced to Australia, and therefore it is eminently appropriate that this provision has been included in the bill which we are now debating.

The Evidence and Procedure (New Zealand) Bill also requires that persons in both courtrooms must be able to see and hear each other where video link is used. Of course, safeguards are essential because when one is cross-examining a witness by video link it is important to be able to detect the demeanour of the witness, so that one is able to ascertain the reliability of the particular witness. That bill also requires that where a telephone is used conference facilities must be available so that persons involved can hear the proceedings.

An important provision in this part of the bill is one which will allow New Zealand counsel to undertake examination, cross-examination and re-examination of witnesses and make submissions in proceedings in an Australian court undertaken in New Zealand by video link or telephone. That provision also makes sense.

Part 5 of the bill deals with the use of video links and telephones in New Zealand proceedings. Similarly, it allows for a New Zealand court to take evidence or receive submissions by video link or telephone. The provisions enable a New Zealand court to exercise any of its powers, excluding its powers to punish for contempt, and to enforce or execute its judgments or process.

The sixth part of the bill is concerned with evidence of certain New Zealand matters. It relates to all proceedings before a court in Australia, including proceedings which relate to bail or sentencing, interlocutory proceedings and those heard in chambers. It provides that proof is not required of New Zealand legislation such as a regulation or a rule of court. A judge may inform himself or herself about these matters as he or she sees fit.

This section also allows for evidence or other official documents to be confirmed by production of a copy of the document. Evidence of a public document which is admissible in New Zealand courts will also be admissible in an Australian court if it purports to be stamped in accordance with the New Zealand act. Part 7 of the bill provides for a number of miscellaneous powers, such as the power of the Governor-General to make regulations prescribing matters under the act.

The Evidence and Procedure (New Zealand) (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1993 complements the Evidence and Procedure (New Zealand) Bill 1993 and makes amendments to the Evidence Act 1905 and the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976. It provides that the transitional bill, the bill and provisions of the acts affected by them do not apply to certain proceedings that have already begun.

Complementary legislation was introduced in the New Zealand parliament last year, and states and territories have supported this after consultation. The coalition has undertaken, as usual with respect to bills coming into the parliament, consultation with a wide range of people in Australia, including Liberal state attorneys-general and the Law Council of Australia. The feedback that we have received collectively is that there is general support for the bill currently before the committee.

It is hoped that the bill will reduce the cost of litigation before Australian courts involving New Zealand elements. It is important to see the continuing cooperation between Australia and New Zealand reach the same level of cooperation as has developed in other areas. I find it difficult to consider New Zealand as a foreign country in any way, shape or form. We on this side of the chamber hold our Australian constitution in very high regard; it has protected the freedoms and stabilities that we enjoy as a nation.

When one refers to the definition section, section 6, of the Australian constitution it is interesting to note that, when the constitution was being negotiated by Australians in Australia from the various colonies, including the grandfather of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer), it was envisaged that New Zealand could well become one of the original states of Australia. Section 6 of the Australian constitution says:
"The Commonwealth" shall mean the Commonwealth of Australia as established under this Act.

"The States" shall mean such of the colonies of New South Wales, New Zealand, Queensland, Tasmania, Victoria, Western Australia, and South Australia, including the northern territory of South Australia, as for the time being are parts of the Commonwealth, and such colonies or territories as may be admitted into or established by the Commonwealth as States; and each of such parts of the Commonwealth shall be called "a State."

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, history records that New Zealand elected not to become part of the Commonwealth of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very ill judged.

—I do not know whether the Premier of Western Australia would agree with the minister's suggestion that it was an ill-judged decision by New Zealand not to become part of the Commonwealth, but facts are facts and on this side of the chamber we are not into rewriting Australian history in the way the government is. The fact of the matter is that New Zealand and Australia are very close allies; the countries are geographically situated close together in the Southern Hemisphere; we have a shared history. Honourable members on this side of the House—and, I believe, most honourable members on the other side also—cherish and honour the Anzac tradition which saw Australia and New Zealand armed forces going into the First World War together. In effect, we have had a very close bond. We have meetings regularly of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General and also of ministers in other portfolio areas and I understand that there is ministerial representation from not only the Commonwealth and the Australian states but also New Zealand. That is eminently appropriate.

PARA.TAB: I think that as much as possible the legal relationship between courts in New Zealand and courts in Australia should be similar to that existing among Australian courts. I think this bill is an important step forward. Of course, it is only a step forward. I hope that the minister and the government will continue to work as much as possible with their New Zealand counterparts with a view to continuing these very important reforms which will facilitate legal proceedings and will encourage the continuing and increasingly close relationship between Australians and New Zealanders. I would also like to advise that the opposition does not oppose the further amendments that the minister has circulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just mention that the establishment of the Main Committee has had a subsidiary effect in relation to me. I have spoken here three times. On two of those occasions I have had to juggle appointments to speak in the House and have had to sprint here to ensure—
—It helps your fitness though, doesn't it?
—It does help, yes. I am not sure that that was the original purpose of the establishment of the chamber. I would hope that other members are undergoing the same exercise.

PARA.TAB: The Evidence and Procedure (New Zealand) Bill 1993 contains arrangements for the use of evidence in Australian and New Zealand courts. In short, the bill facilitates cooperation between Australian and New Zealand courts for the service and enforcement of subpoenas, for the taking of evidence by video link or telephone, to enable Australian courts to take judicial notice of New Zealand laws and to enable proof of New Zealand public and official documents. Specific cooperative evidentiary arrangements have been in place between Australia and New Zealand in relation to antitrust matters since 1990. The act implementing those arrangements, the Trade Practices (Misuse of Trans-Tasman Market Power) Act 1990, implemented Australia's obligations under article 4 of the protocol to the Australia-New Zealand closer economic relations trade agreement on acceleration of free trade in goods. This bill broadens and strengthens those previous arrangements.

The bill is not opposed by the coalition. It serves to expedite and foster economic and social ties between Australia and New Zealand. New Zealand has introduced complementary legislation into its parliament. Part 2 of the bill deals with Australian subpoenas to be served on a party in New Zealand. The part applies to subpoenas issued in a proceeding in a federal court, which includes certain tribunals. If provided by regulation, the part can also apply to subpoenas issued by state and territory courts. Presumably, regulations will be promulgated if requested by a particular state or territory. The part applies to all proceedings except criminal and family proceedings. The exclusion of family proceedings appears to have been made at the request of the New Zealand government.

The subpoena can only be served on a party in New Zealand with the leave of a superior court judge. The judge has wide discretion in determining whether leave might be granted. The bill provides for certain factors that the judge must take into account in making a decision, including the significance of the evidence sought and whether the evidence can be obtained by any other means. The judge must provide a time limit for the subpoena to be served and he or she may impose any other conditions. Once leave is granted, the subpoena may be served on a party in New Zealand in the manner in which the subpoena would have been served in the state or territory in which it was issued.

The party served with the subpoena must comply with it. If the subpoena requires attendance in an Australian court, the party served has a legal obligation to attend. Reasonable expenses must be provided for the purpose. If the subpoena requires the production of documents only, the party served is able to comply with the terms of the subpoena by lodging the documents with any registry of the High Court of New Zealand. A subpoena may be set aside after issue, in limited circumstances.

Part 3 of the bill deals with New Zealand subpoenas. This part contains provisions which complement the procedures in the New Zealand bill equivalent to those in part 2 of this bill. The part creates an obligation in Australian law to comply with a subpoena in appropriate form and correctly served issued by a New Zealand court. The part provides that failure to comply with such a New Zealand subpoena constitutes contempt of the Federal Court of Australia. Presumably, the complementary New Zealand bill provides that failure to comply with an Australian subpoena constitutes contempt of the High Court of New Zealand.

Parts 5 and 6 deal with the use of video links or telephones in Australian and New Zealand proceedings respectively. Part 4 deals with evidence taken from New Zealand by video link or telephone for the purpose of proceedings in a federal court or, if provided by regulations, proceedings in a court of a state or territory. It should be noted that, unlike the subpoena provisions, the part applies to all proceedings and does not exclude criminal and family proceedings. An application must be made to the Australian court for evidence to be taken. A determination by the court is discretionary. In granting an application, the court must be satisfied that reasonable facilities are available and that the evidence can more conveniently be given from New Zealand.

The Australian court is given power to control the giving of evidence in New Zealand. The complementary New Zealand bill will presumably give force in New Zealand law to that right. The bill contains provisions to ensure that all parties can see and hear each other in the case of video link evidence and that all parties can hear each other in the case of telephone evidence. The court has discretion to make orders in relation to the expenses incurred in the taking of the evidence.

Part 5 deals with the taking of evidence by video link or telephone in Australia for use in a New Zealand court. The provisions correspond to those in part 4. They allow the New Zealand court to exercise jurisdiction in relation to the taking of evidence in Australia. They also allow that orders made by New Zealand courts for the purpose of the hearing may be enforced in Australian courts.

Some issues can be raised in relation to the taking of evidence by video link, particularly in relation to part 4 of the bill. These are matters to which I have been alerted as a result of the inquiry of the House Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs into the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill 1994. The objects of that bill had broad bipartisan support. There was legitimate concern, however, as to whether the objects sought to be achieved were achieved by the most appropriate or fair method. The committee produced a carefully considered and detailed advisory report, which has now formed the basis for government amendments to the bill.

The purpose of the child sex tourism bill is widely known. It is designed to enable prosecution in Australia of Australian citizens who engage in sexual activity with minors outside Australia. To facilitate prosecution of those charges, the bill in its current form provides a means whereby evidence of witnesses can be taken by video link from outside Australia. These provisions of the child sex tourism bill were the subject of considerable comment and evidence to the committee. The committee in its advisory report dealt with the concerns raised and made a number of recommendations.

The comparison with the child sex tourism bill is particularly appropriate when it is considered that the provisions of that bill are broadly based on the video link provisions of the bill currently being debated. As noted, the provisions of part 4 of this bill are applicable to criminal as well as civil proceedings. I have no general difficulty with the provisions as they relate to civil proceedings. I do, however, have some concerns in relation to their potential application to criminal proceedings.

It was in the criminal context that the standing committee made its comments in relation to the child sex tourism bill. It noted that the video link provisions potentially infringed the basic right of an accused to confront those who are accusing him or her. That is a right contained in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. To provide for that right is a binding obligation on Australia in international law. Some argued before the committee that evidence by video link breached the spirit of the requirement. It is a fine point, but it is one that bears considering. The ICCPR was drafted at a time prior to the common use of video links. On balance, my view is that the right of confrontation will not be infringed if there is ample opportunity for cross-examination and full visual access by the accused and the jury to the witness. In the case of video link evidence, in this bill the latter is expressly provided for in clause 26. The former is not specifically provided for in the bill. However, the procedure in any criminal trial in an Australian jurisdiction would require a right of full and proper cross-examination. That being the case, while the bill might have been more explicit, the provisions of it do adequately protect the interests of the accused.

That then leads to the question of evidence by telephone. In the case of a witness giving evidence that is adverse to an accused, other than in exceptional circumstances it would be contrary to the interests of justice that a witness be allowed to give evidence by telephone. Generally, a witness adverse to the accused should have to face the accused, the jury and the court visually. Protection of this principle will be left to the good sense of the courts in the exercise of their general discretion. While I am sure that that discretion will be exercised prudently, legislative guidance could have been provided.

As noted earlier, in considering an application for evidence to be heard by video link or telephone, there are two specific criteria that a court must consider in deciding the application, namely, that the court must be satisfied that reasonable facilities are available and that the evidence can more conveniently be given from New Zealand. There is an additional criterion that, in my view, given the applicability to criminal proceedings, should have been included in this bill; that is, that the evidence should not be taken by video link or telephone if it is not in the interests of justice. The requirement to consider such a criterion would in part resolve the difficulty I have expressed concerning witnesses giving evidence in criminal trials. It would direct the court's consideration to the question of prejudice to an accused caused by a remote witness. More generally, it would provide a vital criterion for the court to consider in both criminal and civil proceedings.

The child sex tourism bill specifically required the court not to grant an application for the taking of video link evidence where the direction would be contrary to the interests of justice or, in its amended form, unless it were consistent with the interests of justice. In my view, a similar provision should have been contained in this bill in relation to both video link and telephone evidence.

One point raised by the standing committee in the context of the child sex tourism bill that is equally applicable in this case relates to comments concerning the ability of a court to make orders in relation to expenses incurred in the taking of evidence. In this bill the provision is contained in clause 28. The point made by the committee is that the equivalent provision would not prevent a court making an order against an accused in a criminal trial. The application of the provision should be limited to civil proceedings. In my view it would generally be improper for a court to make a costs order against an accused in a criminal trial.

I conclude discussion of this portion of the bill by commenting on a problematic feature of the child sex tourism bill that is not a difficulty in this case, that is, that while an Australian court can purport to direct the procedure to a hearing taking place in another country, there is no practical power to prevent or sanction a breach of such orders or undertake a prosecution in relation to alleged perjury. That difficulty is alleviated in this bill as a consequence of the mutual arrangements and the complementary New Zealand legislation. That allows an Australian court to enforce New Zealand orders and vice versa.

Turning to part 6 of the bill, this provides that all Australian courts—not just those to which the subpoenas, video link and telephone provisions apply—are to take judicial notice of New Zealand laws and similar instruments. It facilitates proof in Australian courts of New Zealand official acts and documents. This, I think, is a long overdue provision. Without it, it is necessary that there be formal proof of documents requiring witnesses from New Zealand generally and, in addition, to prove New Zealand law it is necessary to call an expert in New Zealand law, which means calling a practitioner who has experience of legal practice in New Zealand. That involves considerable expense. The similarity in the laws between New Zealand and Australia and the similarity in the legal systems is such that it is just as redundant as calling a New South Wales practitioner to give evidence as to New South Wales law in a federal court in Australia. I commend the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) for his contribution to the debate. I also make the very brief comment that the courts will rapidly find this a very convenient way of addressing issues between the Australian and New Zealand jurisdictions, to some considerable advantage to all involved. SPEECH.PARA: I might use this opportunity to address the amendments in general and then move them as appropriate. The government amendments have two purposes: the first is to improve the bill in relation to its application to tribunals; the second is to ensure that all orders made by New Zealand courts or tribunals for the payment of expenses under the corresponding New Zealand legislation will be readily enforceable in Australia. Needless to say, similar provisions have been included in the New Zealand legislation in relation to similar orders made by Australian courts and tribunals.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members will recall that amongst other things the bill provides for enforceable trans-Tasman service of subpoenas and the taking of trans-Tasman evidence by video link or telephone. The bill is essentially concerned with proceedings in courts, but clause 4 enables tribunals to be prescribed so that subpoena and video link provisions apply to them.

Concerning amendments (1) and (2), the first amendment does two things. It enables the regulations to prescribe a particular tribunal for the purposes of subpoena provisions or the video link provisions, or both, instead of only for both sets of provisions as under the current clause. It makes the consequential amendment so that certain references in the bills to a judge will apply to a member of a prescribed tribunal. The second amendment is purely a drafting amendment. It excludes courts, judicial officers and court officers from the definition of `tribunal'.

The third amendment, clause 28, provides for courts to make orders for the payment of expenses incurred in connection with the taking of evidence or the receiving of submissions from New Zealand by video link or telephone. A general principle in Commonwealth tribunals is that orders for the payment of expenses cannot be made in favour of the Commonwealth. However, there are provisions for orders to be made against the Commonwealth for payment of witness expenses. Examples of legislative provisions to that effect include section 67 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act and section 75A of the Sex Discrimination Act.

It would not be appropriate for orders to be made by such tribunals under the bill against persons other than the Commonwealth. Accordingly, the third amendment amends clause 28 to provide that regulations prescribing a Commonwealth tribunal for the purposes of part 4 of the bill may also provide that such a tribunal may not make orders under clause 28 against a person other than the Commonwealth.

The fourth amendment will add a new clause to the bill to provide for the application of the Foreign Judgments Act 1991 to certain orders made under the New Zealand legislation corresponding to this bill. It is important that orders for payment to witnesses in video link evidence under the arrangements in this bill be readily enforceable. Most orders made by New Zealand courts under the corresponding New Zealand legislation will be enforceable by registration under the Foreign Judgments Act 1991. However, some orders, especially those made by tribunals or specialist courts, will not be so enforceable. Accordingly, the new clause added by this provides that all orders by New Zealand courts for the payment of witness expenses and expenses relating to video link evidence will be enforceable under the Foreign Judgments Act. I commend the various amendments to the committee and I hand up three copies of the supplementary explanatory memorandum.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 5 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: Further to the answer by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories to my question without notice (Hansard, 29 September 1993, page 1333), concerning logging in compartment 1402 in the south east forests of New South Wales, in which she indicated that a Commonwealth response to the logging was being discussed with the Minister for Resources, has he or his predecessor informed the responsible NSW Ministers that the relevant woodchip licence may be liable to Commonwealth action if the terms of the National Forest Policy Statement are not adhered to; if not, why not; if so, will he table the letter communicating this information.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The National Forest Policy Statement was developed as a partnership between the Commonwealth, the States and Territories for the future management of Australia's public and private forests on a cooperative basis. Under the Statement, signatory governments made commitments to implement certain initiatives, both individually and collectively but recognising that prime responsibility for land use issues remains with the States and Territories.

The Government believes that the continuation of this cooperative approach between the Commonwealth and the State/Territory Governments is the most appropriate way to ensure the long term protection of old-growth forests and wilderness.

Under the National Forest Policy Statement, a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system for old-growth forests and wilderness is to be in place by 1995 for forests on public lands and by 1998 for private forested land. A Joint Sub-Committee of the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council and Ministerial Council on Forestry, Fisheries and Aquaculture is currently developing criteria for determining this forest reservation system. I understand the criteria are expected to be finalised soon. Once the criteria are agreed, the Commonwealth, States and Territories will work together to ensure that a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system is in place.

As part of this cooperative approach, it was agreed in the National Forest Policy Statement that until forest assessments are completed forest management agencies will avoid activities that may significantly affect those areas of old-growth forest or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value. This was not meant to imply a moratorium on logging in all areas of old-growth and wilderness, only those likely to be required for the forest reservation system. The National Forest Policy Statement recognised that some logging in old-growth areas will continue for some time to meet the demand for timber.

Logging in compartment 1402 was covered by current State environmental impact statements. This compartment was also approved for logging in the context of Harris Daishowa's 1993 export licence following a detailed assessment by the then Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths, under Commonwealth environmental legislation, including the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 and the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992.

In accordance with his legal obligations, Mr Griffiths' assessment included consideration of feasible and prudent alternatives to the proposed operations and means of ensuring that any adverse impacts on the national estate were minimised. It also included consideration of advice from the Australian Heritage Commission.

In the context of the 1994 woodchip export licence renewals the then Minister for Resources, the Hon Michael Lee, MP advised State Ministers that he had indicated to licensees that they should have due regard to the objectives, policies and processes agreed by Governments in the National Forest Policy Statement and should consult with State forest management agencies as appropriate on the adoption of these agreed policies.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 17 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to claims that the level of protection for high conservation value of old growth forests in New South Wales is appallingly low.

(2) Have Dr Norton of the Australian National University and Professor J. Kiremarkpatrick of the University of Tasmania completed a major report which highlights how little high conservation value old growth forest is protected in national parks; if so, does the report state that:

(a) in north eastern New South Wales, (i) 0.8 per cent of dry/cool, (ii) 0.1 per cent of dry/warm, (iii) 5.4 per cent of wet/cool and (iv) 0.9 per cent of wet/warm high conservation value old growth forest on flatter terrain with fertile soils is in reserves;

(b) in south eastern New South Wales (i) in the Eden Management Area virtually no high conservation value old growth forest on fertile soils is in reserves and (ii) in the Batemans Bay forestry region only 7 per cent of old growth forest on the most productive sites is in reserves; and
(c) the best old growth forests have been excluded from national parks.
(3) Is it a fact that 90 per cent of the high conservation value old growth forests are available for logging.
(4) Does he accept the accuracy of the data provided in the report.
(5) What steps will the Government take to stop logging and woodchipping of important old growth forests.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am aware of community concerns that old-growth forests with high conservation value should be protected.

(2) (a), (b) I understand that Dr Norton and Professor Kirkpatrick have prepared a paper which contains the figures referred to in the honourable member's question and that these are based upon a study compiled by another author.

(c) The paper claims that land ownership and allocation decisions in the past have created a system of forest reserves that are not representative of old-growth forests and forest biodiversity. At the same time the paper acknowledges initiatives in the National Forest Policy Statement for the development of a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system for forest and wilderness areas which will be complemented by off-reserve forest management.

(3) I understand that the paper does not assert that 90 per cent of the high conservation value old-growth forests are available for logging nor does it define "high conservation value old-growth forest". While the paper estimates that for three forest groups in NSW, some 10 per cent occurs in conservation reserves, this does not imply that the balance is available for logging as State Forests are subject to various management prescriptions which may significantly limit areas able to be harvested.
(4) Without knowing the basis on which old-growth forests are defined or the methodology adopted to produce the data in the report I am unable to comment on the accuracy of the report.

(5) The Commonwealth and mainland States have agreed in the National Forest Policy Statement to a cooperative approach to protect old-growth forests and wilderness and a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system is to be in place by 1995 for public forests. As part of this cooperative approach, it was agreed in the National Forest Policy Statement that until forest assessments are completed forest management agencies will avoid activities that may significantly affect those areas of old-growth forest or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value. This was not meant to imply a moratorium on logging in all areas of old-growth and wilderness, only those likely to be required for the forest reservation system. The National Forest Policy Statement recognised that some logging in old-growth areas will continue for some time to meet the demand for timber.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 3 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did he receive my letter of 13 August 1993, which I wrote on behalf of a constituent, regarding allegations about abuse of human rights in Vietnam; if so, why has he neither acknowledged receipt nor replied to my correspondence.
(2) What is the level of commitment of the government to the protection of human rights in Vietnam.
(3) Are limitations on trade and foreign aid appropriate mechanisms for reducing instances of human rights abuse in Vietnam.
(4) Was a human rights delegation established in May 1993 with a view to investigating allegations of human rights abuse in Vietnam; if so, what progress has it made.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I did receive the Honourable Member's letter. The delay, for which I apologise, was due to an oversight in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

(2) The Government affirms that human rights are both universal in application and indivisible in scope. It sees a dialogue on human rights as an important part of our bilateral relationship with all countries, including Vietnam. During my visit to Vietnam in April 1994, I raised with the Vietnamese Government specific cases of human rights concern.

(3) The Government's approach has been to build a productive and broad-ranging relationship with Vietnam. The Government regards this as providing an effective and constructive context for addressing human rights issues.

(4) Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet agreed, during his visit to Australia in May 1993, to the visit of an Australian parliamentary delegation to have a first-hand look at the human rights situation. I confirmed arrangements for the visit of a Parliamentary Consultative Delegation during my visit to Vietnam in April 1994, the details of which were announced by my colleague, Senator Evans, on 5 May 1994. Unfortunately, the subsequent decision by the Vietnamese Government to deny a visa to one member of the delegation and scale back the delegation's program has made it necessary for us to decide not to proceed with the proposed visit at this time.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Pensions: Effect of Unrealised Capital Gains

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 3 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many pensioners have lost (a) all or (b) part of their pensions administered by his Department as a result of the Government's treatment of unrealised capital gains as income and the calculation of rates of return on their investments for the purposes of the pensions income and assets test.
(2) What is the net savings to his Department of the new provisions and the cancellation of part or all of the pensions.
(3) How many extra staff have been required to implement the new provisions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The assessment of income using a rate of return which takes into account both changes in capital value on the investment and dividends or income distributions made over the previous 12 months applies to certain managed investments and listed shares.

For managed investments, this approach applies to investments acquired after 1 January 1988 (for friendly society bonds) and 9 September 1988 (for market linked investments). In March 1993, the way in which the rate of return is determined changed in relation to market linked investments, with the rate of return assessable over the preceding 12 months being based on the investment's actual performance and the 11% ceiling rate of return removed.
From 20 September 1993, similar rules were introduced for listed shares acquired after 18 August 1992.

Since the above changes took effect, there have been quarterly bulk reassessments of the income earned by managed investments and listed shares acquired after 18 August 1992. These bulk reassessments resulted in the following changes for pensioners with such investments on the 6 January 1994 update:
43,850 or 62% of all cases with managed investments or shares had no change in their rate of payment.
15,000 or 21.5% of all cases with managed investments or shares received an average $4.00 increase;
11,650 or 16.5% of all cases with managed investments or shares received an average $7.30 reduction;
158 or 0.2% of all cases with managed investments or shares had their pensions cancelled with an average $30 pf reduction.
Of these cases, some pensioners held managed investments only, some held shares only, and some held both shares and managed investments.

It is not possible to provide such a breakdown for the June 1993, September 1993 or March 1994 quarterly updates as the only figures obtainable include a range of pension and threshold indexation rises which mask the individual impact of managed investments and shares.

It should be noted that a client whose pension is cancelled at one bulk update may be regranted before the next update and their rate amended because of that update. Also, a client whose rate decreases as a result of one bulk update may have a rate increase at the next bulk update because the overall currently assessed return on their managed investments and/or shares has decreased.
(2) The estimated net savings from the application of the new rules referred to above are;
for managed investments it is only possible to provide the overall effect of a package of proposals, some of considerable benefit to pensioners such as the offsetting of losses against profits:

PARA.TAB: (3) Additional funds for staffing required to implement the new provisions was $87,000 in 1992/93.
Ongoing funds are 40,000 per annum.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 3 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: Has he or his Department reviewed the effectiveness of the whistleblower legislation before the Queensland and New South Wales Parliaments; if so, what plans and progress have been made to introduce similar legislation for the Australian Public Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: I am advised that my Department has not formally reviewed the effectiveness of the whistleblower legislation currently before the Queensland and New South Wales Parliaments, although it continues to monitor legislative developments relating to whistleblowing in all Australian jurisdictions. The Government has been examining proposals for legislation to protect whistleblowers as part of its consideration of recommendations made by the Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law (conducted by the Gibbs Committee) on the disclosure of official information. The question of introducing such legislation is also being examined by the Senate Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing, which is due to report by 30 June 1994 but which may be delayed into August due to the illness of Senator Newman.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 4 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that following the presentation of a case to the Australian Federal Police (AFP) by Mr Rod Barret of Emerald, Qld, Mr Barret has been advised that the case will not be investigated until another unassociated case is presented in the Emerald area; if so, is this normal procedure.
(2) When was the last case presented to the AFP in the Emerald area.
(3) What is the time frame before a single case in a rural area is investigated.
(4) What criteria are used to judge the priority of a case.
(5) Who determines the criteria.
(6) Will he investigate the matter referred to in part (1).

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The case in question relates to possible breaches of the Bankruptcy Act 1966 referred to the Australian Federal Police (AFP) by the Director of Public Prosecutions Office in Brisbane, not by Mr Barret. The matter was given a medium to low priority when assessed by the AFP. On 23 November 1993 Mr Barret was advised verbally that the investigation would be conducted when resources became available.
(2) The last case presented in the Emerald area was in March 1993; however, the priority of that investigation did not allow the allocation of resources to the case in question.
(3) The time frame for investigating rural area matters is dependent upon a number of factors, and can range from immediate in high priority matters to a delay in low priority matters.

(4) The priority of a referral is assessed on AFP policy on investigating fraud and general crime on the Commonwealth. It is largely based on the evaluation of the AFP's capacity to respond, justification for applying police resources and the priority of other cases requiring attention.
(5) The criteria are developed at a national level and applied by Branch management at Regional level.
(6) The matter is in the hands of the AFP and will be investigated in accordance with its priorities.

PARA.TAB: (4) Has his Department conducted or commissioned any surveys or studies which examine successful employment outcomes for periods longer than three months after program completion; if so, what were the findings.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The most recently available post program data available are for the 12 months ending March 1994. The proportions of program participants obtaining non-subsidised employment and positive outcomes (an unsubsidised job or non-DEET education/training place) were as follows:

(2) The Post Program Monitoring survey attempts to collect information from all former program participants apart from those who have undertaken a JOBSTART placement where, given the large numbers of participants, a 50% sample is used. The average proportion of responses from clients included in the survey in the year to end March 1994 was 70%, yielding outcomes estimates that are in general accurate to within plus or minus one percentage point.

(3) Post Program Monitoring survey data provide no information on the causal link between program participation and unsubsidised employment outcomes. However, the issue of what role program intervention plays in relation to outcomes has been addressed in recent program evaluations. This has been done by measuring the net impact of the program. Measuring the net impact involves an assessment of the effect of program participation on a person's chances of obtaining a job by comparing the outcomes of participants with those of a comparable group of Commonwealth Employment Service clients who did not receive similar program assistance. The difference between the two sets of outcomes is the `net impact' of the program or the proportion of the program outcome that can be attributed to the program intervention.

Since 1991 the Department has conducted net impact studies using this methodology for the JOBSTART, JOBTRAIN, SkillShare and Job Clubs programs. The net impacts of these programs were 30, 11, 12 and 11 percentage points respectively.

(4) Evaluation studies have shown employment (including subsidised employment) outcomes six to eight months after program participation to be 60% for JOBSTART, 34% for JOBTRAIN, 36% for SkillShare and 44% for Job Clubs.

At twelve months after program participation outcomes data were collected in the NEIS and ATS evaluations only. The evaluation of NEIS showed that 54% of former participants were in self employment and a further 9% were in other employment. The evaluation of ATS showed that 87% of former participants were in employment.
At twenty-four months after program participation, employment outcomes data were collected in the ATS evaluation only. Some 87% of ATS participants were found to be in jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 31 May 1994:

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Tourists enter Australia on a visitor visa. As a condition of this visa, they are not permitted to undertake full-time tertiary studies in Australia. However, they may undertake informal courses of up to three months' duration which do not lead to an award. DEET and DIEA liaise with education institutions to ensure they are aware of all regulations and visa categories with conditions relating to access to formal education. DEET has recently sent to all higher education institutions the latest DIEA classification details on visas and entry permits, together with a reminder to verify the enrolment status of all students, particularly those who claim permanent resident status. (2) Tourists can apply for a tax file number (TFN) from the Australian Taxation Office if they provide proof of identity. They may have a legitimate reason for requiring a TFN. 22 September 1992
29 April 1993
7 June 1993
29 November 1993
3 December 1993

(b) Of the nine communications, three have been declared inadmissible by the United Nations Human Rights Committee without reference to the Australian Government. Of the six remaining communications, three concern the criminal justice system, one is in the area of family law, one deals with the treatment of refugee applicants and the final complaint concerns the Tasmanian Criminal Code which makes consensual sexual contact between adult men in private a criminal offence. (3) What criteria has the Minister established for deciding when to exercise ministerial discretion to waive the health requirements for entry by immigrants.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I have exercised my powers of intervention on 10 occasions in respect of applicants failing to meet the health requirement.
(2) Reasons for decisions in 6 of the cases have been tabled and are therefore available through the Table Office. Tabling of the reasons in respect to the other 4 cases is in progress.
(3) Sections 115 and 137 of the Migration Act provide an intervention power where the Minister thinks that it is in the public interest to do so. The criteria established for this purpose are that:
(i) the circumstances of the case are such that the Migration Regulations could not have anticipated them;
(ii) the consequences of not having recognised the circumstances in the Migration Regulations were clearly not intended;

(iii) the applicant presents strong compassionate circumstances of such an order that failure to recognise them would result in irreparable harm and continuing hardship to an Australian citizen or lawful permanent resident aggrieved by the decision; and
(iv) the applicant would bring substantial economic or cultural benefit to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 7 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did he state that Australian business groups were scaremongering about the unfair dismissal provisions in recently implemented industrial relations legislation and were worrying small business.

(2) Has he proposed changes to the unfair dismissal provisions which will result in business proprietors paying salary for 6 months to unfairly dismissed award workers and $30,000 to non-award workers earning less than $60,000 per annum; if so, how will the changes address the concerns of small business proprietors.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I stated on 18 May 1994 that the Opposition and some employer groups were scaremongering about the termination provisions introduced by the Industrial Relations Reform Act 1993 and that this had made small business, in particular, apprehensive about the new laws.

(2) Following wide consultation with groups including the Business Council of Australia, small and medium sized employers and the ACTU, I announced the Government's intention to make a number of changes to the termination provisions of the Industrial Relations Act 1988.
The decision to act was taken in direct response to some employers' views that the unfair dismissal

ANSWER.PARA: provisions are an impediment to the employment of new staff.

PARA.TAB: Contrary to the implication in the honourable member's question, the changes will not result in employers being required to pay 6 months salary to unfairly dismissed award workers and $30,000 to unfairly dismissed non-award workers whose wages are $60,000 per year or less. In fact, these will be the maximum amounts that the Industrial Relations Court will be able to award to an unfairly dismissed employee by way of compensation, where reinstatement is impracticable. The 6 months salary limit is similar to the limits applicable in New South Wales and Western Australia.

The changes to the termination provisions will remove the uncertainty amongst some employers about the new minimum standards and give employers the confidence to take on new staff without the fear of their businesses being jeopardised by the threat of unduly large compensation payments.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, upon notice, on 8 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Do customs regulations prohibit the taking of duty free goods on board ocean liners by overseas visitors leaving Australia; if so, why.

(2) Are overseas visitors travelling by sea required to make duty free goods they have purchased available to ship's officers before the vessel departs Australia; if so, does this deter visitors from buying duty free goods by necessitating their transport, often at the visitor's cost, to the port of departure for inspection, if necessary, by Customs officers.
(3) What action will the Government take on the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Customs regulations do not prohibit the taking of duty free goods on board ocean liners by visitors leaving Australia. However, the proof-of-export arrangements available for off-airport duty free sales to air travellers whereby the traveller receives the goods in a sealed bag for presentation beyond the Customs barrier are not available for sales to sea travellers.

There are two reasons for this. The first is that there is no provision in the legislation for duty free goods to be delivered in sealed bags to sea travellers at the time of purchase. The second is that the arrangements for proof of export which are available for air travellers, that is, the "plucking" of invoices from sealed bags at airports by representatives of the duty free operators, are not able to be conveniently provided by the duty free operators at waterfront locations.
The Government is planning to amend the legislation to permit use of the sealed bag system by sea travellers and will do so as soon as the amendments can be fitted into the legislative program.

(2) In the meantime the arrangements for duty free sales to sea travellers necessarily require "under bond" movement whereby the duty free shop operator takes the goods from the shop and delivers them beyond the Customs barrier to the ship or wharf.

The Government is aware that some differences have arisen between shipping operators and duty free operators over which organisation should have responsibility for delivery of the goods into the possession of the traveller. This is essentially a matter which must be resolved between these bodies. The main concern of Government and Customs is to ensure that there is satisfactory proof of export; otherwise the duty free operator is liable for the duty concerned.

In the case of travellers who intend departing Australia by sea and who make purchases other than at the city of departure, the goods would have to be transported by the shop operator to the port of departure. There apparently have been instances where duty free shop operators have not made sales to sea travellers in such circumstances because the operator was not prepared to transport the purchases to the ship or wharf at the port of departure.

(3) When the legislation is amended, duty free shop operators will have the choice of either delivering purchases to sea travellers in sealed bags and then plucking the associated invoices beyond the Customs barrier at the waterfront, or arranging delivery of the purchases to sea travellers after the traveller has passed the barrier.
In either case the responsibility to establish proof of export will remain firmly on the duty free operator; otherwise the operator must pay the duty concerned.
